awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Blue-Noise Graph Sampling
awd_abstract_narration:
This project presents a collaborative research and education effort in graph signal processing where interesting phenomena in nature can often be captured by graphs since objects and data are invariably interrelated in some sense.  Social networks, ecological networks, and the human brain are a few examples of such networks. A feature that these networks of interest have in common, is that they define very large graphs. Algorithms used to compute properties of complete graphs, rapidly become impractical when the graphs under study become very large. Graph sampling thus becomes essential. The research explores a somewhat radical departure from the prior work on graph sampling and is based on the notion of stochastic sampling in irregular sampling grids. In concert with the advancing the scientific goals of the project, the investigators will also jointly develop a short course on graph signal processing and its applications so as to introduce this emerging field to a broad set of students.

While fixed-time sampling is well known, this project focuses on stochastic sampling theory to graph signal processing and, in particular, graph sub-sampling with and without knowledge of the signal. In the case of sampling without signal knowledge, investigators intend to design optimal sub-sampling grids that minimize low frequency energy in a binary signal where investigators intend to develop low computational complexity dither algorithms that closely mimic the ideal patterns. In the case of sub-sampling with signal knowledge, the developed adaptive sub-sampling algorithms will adjust the sampling rate based on the local frequency content of the signal to, thereby, sample at just above the Nyquist rate of the sample within a small region of interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Graphs are data structured used in computer science as a way to organize packets of information that otherwise have no distinguishable or measureable quantity by which to order information from smallest to largest.  An example would be social networks that connect persons, for instance, most strongly to family members, weakly to friends, and without any connections between strangers.  The notion of a smooth signal is to say that packets represented a quantity, like a person's age, so that direct neighbors are expected to have a similar value of this quantity.  So a smooth graph would place a particular age group of subjects at one end and an opposing age group at another.  

The notion of signal sampling is to say that we want to preserve the data packets associated with a small set of nodes, discarding the rest.  If the graph is smooth, as described above, we expect to be able to reconstruct the discarded nodes from the ones we preserved.  The scientific merit of this project was to identify computationally efficient algorithms for choosing which packets of information to keep knowing that we wanted to best reconstruct the discarded nodes.  The specific strategies for choosing these nodes was based on a random process that attempted to homogeneously space the preserved nodes so that no two preseved nodes were direct neighbors of each other.  As a random process, the sampling methods we introduced can be applied without the exhaustive search used by the current state of the art methods -- meaning our methods could be performed quickly as well as be applied to large graphs otherwise requiring too much processing to be considered practical.  To this end, we introduced a sampling algorithm that can be applied to large graphs by partitioning the graph and then sampling each partition in parallel.

In addition to simple graphs where nodes were connected together according to a single set of edges, we also investigated multigraphs where nodes are connected together by multiple sets of edges similar to having graphs laid on top of other graphs.  Multilayer graphs then represent connections between packets based on different criteria.  In this project, we extended our random sampling algorithm to involve the evaluation of these many criteria when state of the art methods focused on merging the many criteria into a single unifying graph which does not necessarily produce aggregate sampling patterns with ideal characteristics. As an applicaiton of multigraph sampling, we investigated the sampling and reconstruction of multispectral color point clouds, constructing graphs from the component spectral recordings where neighboring points in the cloud were connected to their nearest neighbors with weights derived from the change in signal intensity for the corresponding colors.  Sampling and reconstruction experiments demonstrated that the proposed methods of sampling based on blue-noise and that incorporate the multiple graph layers were superior to state of the art methods that merge graphs into a single unifying network. 

This research effort was carried by two PhD students and resulted in a graduate level graph signal processing course in Electrical and Computer Engineering being developed that will be offered starting in the Fall of 2023 at the University of Kentucky by the PI.
